Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as a threat to individual freedom of speech, opinion, and expression.
The definitions of misinformation and disinformation are perceived as tools for government censorship.
The proposal is viewed as a means for the government to enforce propaganda and become totalitarian.
The assurances of privacy and freedom of speech protections are considered insubstantial.
There is concern about the potential for massive fines and penalties to enforce compliance.
The submission references the Universal Declaration of Human Rights to argue against the legislation.
The existing E Safety Commission is seen as sufficient for protecting individuals from misinformation.
Notable Quotes: My view on the Exposure Draft Bill is that it is designed to limit individual freedom of speech/opinion/expression by allowing a government entity to regulate privately owned digital platforms.
The thinly veiled assurances that the Bill includes 'strong protections for privacy and freedom of speech' offer nothing substantive in the way of said protections.
The passage of this Bill would be an assault on the civil liberties of Australians.
